TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class EditModePanel : System.Web.UI.WebControls.Panel, System.Web.UI.INamingContainer
.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit EditModePanel extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.Panel implements class System.Web.UI.INamingContainer, class System.Web.UI.IParserAccessor
Public NotInheritable Class EditModePanel Inherits Panel Implements INamingContainer
public ref class EditModePanel sealed : System::Web::UI::WebControls::Panel, System::Web::UI::INamingContainer

Docs.summary: Provides a container that shows or hides its child controls based on the mode of the page.

remarks.para: When a page is viewed in a Web browser it will be in one of two page display modes: Edit mode or Display mode. Readers can only view pages in Display mode. Authors can view pages in either mode. You can use the control to control the visibility of other controls in relation to the Display mode. For example, if you are a page designer, you can add a field to the page's content type that is only used to include business logic for page authors. You can use the control to allow page authors to view and edit when the page is in Edit mode yet hide the information from readers when the page is in Display mode.

You can also use the control to insert information only at display time while hiding it at edit time. For example, a page designer might have one set of cascading style sheet classes that should be used in Display mode and a different set that should be used only in Edit mode. The l control has a custom run-time designer that is used when a page contains an control in Microsoft SharePoint Designer or Visual Studio. This control designer allows the user to edit the content inside of an in the same way that they would edit content contained within a <DIV> tag or a table cell.

example.code: ///In this example, the EditModePanel control is used to display and ///edit two fields which drive some of the business logic of the site. <PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel runat="server" id="BusinessLogicArea" style="margin:5px; border:solid 1px black; background-color:#7ba2d6"> <table> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="color:white; font-size:18px; font-weight:bold;">Product Properties</td> </tr> <tr> <td style="vertical-align:top; padding-right: 20px;"> <SharePointWebControls:LookupField runat="server" id-="RelatedProduct" FieldName="Product Supplier" /> </td> <td style="vertical-align:top;"> <SharePointWebControls:DropDownChoiceField runat="server" FieldName="Model Year" /> </td> </tr> </table> </PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel> ///In this example, the EditModePanel control is used to determine///whether the CSS file included is for display or editing. <PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel runat="server" id="GetDisplayCss" PageDisplayMode="Display" SuppressTag="true"> <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/MyStyles/Display.css" > </PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel> <PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel runat="server" id="GetEditCss" PageDisplayMode="Edit" SuppressTag="true"> <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/MyStyles/Edit.css" > </PublishingWebControls:EditModePanel>

Protected Overrides Sub AddParsedSubObject (obj As Object)

Docs.param: Parsed sub object to add to the control collection
Docs.summary: Adds parsed sub objects to the control collection only if the EditModePanel is going to render in the current mode

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::SharePoint::Publishing::WebControls::PageDisplayMode PageDisplayMode { Microsoft::SharePoint::Publishing::WebControls::PageDisplayMode get(); void set(Microsoft::SharePoint::Publishing::WebControls::PageDisplayMode value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether this control is visible in Edit mode or Display mode.

remarks.para: The property is used to determine whether the child controls are displayed in Edit mode or Display mode.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance void RenderBeginTag(class System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter writer) cil managed
Public Overrides Sub RenderBeginTag (writer As HtmlTextWriter)

Docs.param: A that represents the output stream that renders HTML content on the client.
Docs.summary: Renders the HTML opening tag of the control to the specified writer if enabled.

remarks.para: The base class renders an opening <DIV> tag before it outputs child controls. You can use the method to override the method from the base class and suppress this opening tag. If the property is set to true, this method will suppress the generation of the opening tag. Otherwise, the opening tag will be generated by the base class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance void RenderEndTag(class System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter writer) cil managed
Public Overrides Sub RenderEndTag (writer As HtmlTextWriter)

Docs.param: A that represents the output stream to render HTML content on the client.
Docs.summary: Renders the HTML closing tag of the control to the specified writer..

remarks.para: The base class will render a closing tag after it outputs its child controls. You can use the RenderEndTag method to override the method from the base class in order to suppress this closing tag. If the property is true, this method will suppress the generation of the closing tag. Otherwise, the closing tag will be generated by the base class.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool SuppressTag { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether this control will render an outer <DIV> element.

remarks.para:
Because the control derives from the ASP.NET Panel control, it will naturally emit
and
tags around its child content. The property enables you to suppress the generation of these opening and closing elements. One scenario in which this would be very useful is the section of the page where the control is used to generate, for example, metatags, cascading style sheet links, or script links. The default value is false.
